title: The Negative (De/Den)
reading_greek:
THE RULE
Δεν + Verb

EXAMPLES
1. Δεν έχω χρόνο. (I don't have time.)
2. Δεν είμαι καλά. (I am not well.)
3. Ο Πέτρος δεν μένει εδώ. (Peter doesn't live here.)
4. Δεν θέλω τίποτα. (I don't want anything.)
5. Δεν καταλαβαίνω. (I don't understand.)

DEN vs DE
6. Δεν ξέρω. (I don't know - 'Den' before vowels or k, p, t)
7. Δε θέλω. (I don't want - 'De' before other consonants, usually spoken)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: NEGATION [(See Page 35)](/assets/grammar.pdf#page=35)

1. PLACEMENT: 'Den' always goes BEFORE the verb.
   - NOT 'Exo den'.
   - YES 'Den exo'.

2. DOUBLE NEGATIVE: Greek LOVES double negatives.
   - 'Den thelo tipota' = I don't want nothing. (Correct in Greek!)

3. PRONUNCIATION: The final 'n' in 'Den' is sometimes dropped in rapid speech before continuous consonants (De thelo), but writing 'Δεν' is always safe.
audio_script:
The Negative! How to say 'No' inside a sentence. 

Use 'DEN'. 
Rule 1: Put it BEFORE the verb. 'Den exo' (I don't have). 
Rule 2: Don't be afraid of double negatives. 'Den thelo tipota' (I don't want nothing) is perfectly correct Greek. 

Note on Sound: You might hear 'De' instead of 'Den'. 'De thelo'. This happens when the next word starts with a continuous sound like 'th', 'v', 'l'. But 'Den' is always correct to write.
